Yes, the Peshwas had several methods to encourage cultivators to pay their taxes on time. One of the most important methods was to provide incentives to the cultivators. The Peshwas often gave rewards in the form of tax exemptions to those who paid their taxes on time or in advance. This helped to create a sense of competition among cultivators to pay their taxes early and avoid the penalties.

Another method that the Peshwas used was to provide loans to the cultivators who couldn't pay their taxes on time. These loans were given at a low-interest rate and were designed to help the cultivators avoid the penalties that they would otherwise have to pay.

The Peshwas also employed revenue officials who were responsible for collecting taxes. These officials were trained to handle cultivators carefully and to make sure that they understood the importance of paying taxes on time. The officials would often visit the villages and explain the benefits of paying taxes on time to the cultivators.

Moreover, the Peshwas implemented a system of rewards for revenue officials who collected taxes efficiently and quickly. The officials were given bonuses and promotions for their good work, and this incentivized them to collect taxes as efficiently as possible.

Overall, the Peshwas' administration implemented several methods to encourage cultivators to pay their taxes on time to ensure that the revenue collection system worked efficiently. These methods included incentives, loans, training of revenue officials, and rewards for good work, all of which helped to ensure that taxes were collected on time.
